thread.title: To reduce gun violence, voters strongly support tackling mental illness, OPB poll finds
thread.title_full: To reduce gun violence, voters strongly support tackling mental illness, OPB poll finds | OregonLive.com

author: Jeff Mapes | The Oregonian/OregonLive
title: To reduce gun violence, voters strongly support tackling mental illness, OPB poll finds
text:
A new poll taken after the mass shooting in Roseburg found that Oregon voters remain deeply divided over gun control but do support some specific actions to decrease gun violence.
The survey taken for Oregon Public Broadcasting found that voters overwhelmingly believe that mental health problems are a prime cause of mass shootings – and they're willing to support several policies aimed at grappling with the problems of gun violence and mental illness.
OPB also surveyed Washington voters and found similar results .
When asked to consider five different causes for mass shootings, the strongest majorities focused on mental health. Eighty-four percent of Oregon voters said they thought mass shootings are "mostly the result of unidentified and untreated mental health problems."
Respondents to the OPB poll were much more closely divided about whether the existing gun laws are too lenient or too strict.
Forty-five percent said it's too easy for violent people to obtain firearms while 53 percent disagree.
At the same time, 41 percent said the laws were too strict and that mass shooters could be stopped if more people were carrying guns and ready to defend themselves. Fifty-four percent disagreed with that contention.
This sharp divide is seen in national surveys, which show Americans split between those who think it is more important to protect gun rights and those who want to control gun ownership.
In the OPB poll, a strong majority of Oregon voters – 68 percent -- said they support mandatory mental health screening before someone could purchase "assault guns, including semi and fully automatic rifles."
In addition, 69 percent said they support higher taxes to support more mental health treatment. And 55 percent said they favor making it "easier to institutionalize someone who is showing signs of mental health problems that could lead to violence."
While there is widespread concern about mental illness and gun violence, many experts note that those with mental illness are more likely to be the victims of crime than to engage in violence and that it is hard to identify who is at risk of violent behavior.
The Oregon Legislature took one step toward dealing with mental illness and gun violence by passing legislation that directed judges to decide whether they should remove a person's gun rights while they are undergoing court-ordered mental health treatment. That was included in a highly debated bill expanding background checks to cover private gun transfers.
The OPB poll found that 74 percent support taking gun rights away from someone convicted of a violent misdemeanor. Currently, the law bars felons from possessing guns , as well as those convicted of misdemeanor domestic violence and those convicted of misdemeanors carrying a maximum term of more than year in prison.
Three-fourths of voters said they support a waiting period to purchase guns and 62 percent said they back limiting the number of firearms that someone can purchase at one time.
Nearly half -- 49 percent -- said more law-abiding citizens should be encouraged to carry concealed handguns so they are prepared to "stop a mass shooter before he starts" while 46 percent are opposed.
At the same time, 58 percent said they would oppose increasing taxes on ammunition for some types of guns to make them more expensive to use.
The OPB poll was conducted by DHM Research of Portland and has a margin of error of 4.9 percentage points, plus or minus.
The Oct. 8-11 telephone survey included 400 Oregonians and 400 Washingtonians likely to vote in the 2016 election.
